content: Hakka stir-fried taro dumplings **Abacus seeds** ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 算盘子) or **abacus beads** is a [Hakka Chinese dish](/wiki/Hakka_cuisine) consisting of dimpled, disc-shaped [dumplings](/wiki/Dumplings) made with [taro](/wiki/Taro) and [tapioca flour](/wiki/Tapioca). The dumplings are boiled then stir-fried with minced pork, [shiitake](/wiki/Shiitake) or [wood ear mushrooms](/wiki/Auricularia_heimuer), [dried shrimp](/wiki/Dried_shrimp), dried cuttlefish and firm [bean curd](/wiki/Bean_curd). Due to its association with the [abacus](/wiki/Abacus) and counting money, the dish is eaten during festivals such as [Chinese New Year](/wiki/Chinese_New_Year) to signify wealth and prosperity. The dumplings' round shape is also said to represent reunion and good health. It can be found in parts of [China](/wiki/China), [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia) and [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), and in cities with a large [Hakka](/wiki/Hakka_people) population. ## History Abacus seeds date back to the [Song dynasty](/wiki/Song_dynasty). It was prepared by Hakka women for the men of the village to carry with them when they ventured out to look for work. The dish was both a food and also a symbolic wish that the men would find success and earn more money to count with an abacus. ## Gallery - Food portal - [List of dumplings](/wiki/List_of_dumplings) Part of a series on[Chinese cuisine](/wiki/Chinese_cuisine)[Regional cuisines](/wiki/Chinese_regional_cuisine)Four Great Traditions -
